newsitem.title: FRANCE: France defends oil, gas deals with Iran. [CORRECTED 18:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: France defends oil, gas deals with Iran. [CORRECTED 18:00 GMT]

text.p: France defended on Tuesday the right of its oil companies to sign contracts with Iran despite unilateral U.S. sanctions, saying Tehran was not subject to any international embargo.
Iran's Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said on Sunday that Tehran had awarded a contract to develop its major South Pars gas field to French oil company Total SA.
The company denied it had signed a deal but said it was interested in the project and talks were continuing.
Oil experts said the contract, reported to be worth $3.5 billion, would require the single biggest investment in the Islamic republic since its 1979 revolution.

The United States has passed legislation to punish foreign oil firms which make investments of more than $40 million (corrects from $50 million) in Iran but the European Union has ordered its firms to pay no heed to the U.S. law.

"The activities of French companies in Iran are entirely legal. There is no international restriction or embargo on Iran," Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a regular briefing on Tuesday.
He noted that U.S. oil companies Mobil and Conoco had attended an energy conference in the Iranian city of Isfahan this month alongside French firms.
An official at Iran's state oil company said talks on the South Pars contract were still continuing with Total and also with a rival consortium led by the Anglo-Dutch oil giant Royal Dutch Shell.
Total and Shell have led groups of European and Asian firms aiming to develop South Pars produce 56.64 million cubic metres a day of gas after five years of project work.
Total is already the leading foreign oil investor in Iran after scooping a $600 million deal in 1995 to develop its Sirri E and A offshore gas fields, the latter of which starts production next year.

Relations between Iran and the European Union have been strained since a German court last month implicated top Iranian leaders in the assassination of three dissident Kurds and their translator in Berlin's Mykonos restaurant in 1992.
The EU collectively withdrew its ambassadors from Tehran and suspended ministerial contacts with the Islamic republic after the verdict. Iran strenuously denied the allegations.
